div.p: Here in Malaysian Borneo, a seasonal invasion is underway.
Staff at hotels watch nervously for a food that is
...smelly
...awful
...and loved by millions.
Meet the durian fruit.
Its smell is hard to describe.
"It smells like a rotten fish and custard."
"A rubbish dump."
"Bleu cheese."
"Perhaps a dead dog."
"Like private parts."
Many cultures love foods that have a really strong smell.
For example cheese, a favorite in the West, is actually rotted milk...a smell people in Asia find disgusting.
And like cheese in France, durian is precious in Southeast Asia.
Some even believe it’s worth killing for.
Durian trees don’t bear fruit until they’re fifteen years old.
And it doesn’t come cheap either. A single durian can cost as much as fifty US dollars.
Here in Kuching, the capital of Malaysian Borneo, hotels are on the front lines of the durian war.
When the fruit is in season, hotel managers maintain a constant vigil to keep it out.
For them, the problem is really about money. One smelly durian fruit can scare off a hotel full of customers.
"It goes into the curtains. It sticks into the carpet. It sticks into the bedspreads.”
That doesn’t stop people from trying to smuggle it in.
"We can immediately smell it, and they always deny it, but we know that they’ve got them.”
Every hotel has its own method of dealing with a durian alert.
"There are only two methods of getting rid of the smell we've found."
"One is charcoal. Charcoal absorbs the smell. And the other...that takes quite a long time."
"And the other one...we’ve got an ionizer that...it’s an industrialized one, and within three hours we can pull the smell out of the room.”
"Please no durians here, not in the hotel. Outside...in the fresh air you can do it. But definitely not here."
In Borneo, visitors can decide for themselves if the durian is delicious, or just plain disgusting...
as long as they do their taste testing outdoors.
